Introduction

Uterine sarcomas are a rare and aggressive group of malignancies that arise from the mesenchymal tissue of the uterus.  They account for approximately 3%-7% of all uterine cancers and have a poor prognosis compared to endometrial carcinomas.

Pathogenesis



The most common uterine malignancy (endometrial cancer) arises from the endometrium and tends to be more amenable to treatment.  In contrast, uterine sarcomaâ€”a broad term that encompasses multiple malignanciesâ€”arises from the myometrial or stromal elements of the uterus.  They are rare, aggressive, and difficult to treat.



Uterine sarcomas arise from genetic mutations in tumor suppressor genes (eg, TP53, PTEN) and oncogenes, leading to unregulated cellular proliferation within the uterine mesenchyme.  Uterine sarcomas arise independently, not from benign leiomyomas (fibroids).

Risk factors



  • Long-term tamoxifen use (>5 years):  Associated with an increased risk; however, the absolute risk is low.
  • Radiation exposure:  Particularly prior pelvic radiation.
  • Hereditary conditions (eg, hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell carcinoma [HLRCC], hereditary retinoblastoma).

Pathology



Uterine sarcomas are classified into homologous and heterologous subcategories.  Homologous uterine sarcomas contain tissue that is typically found only within the uterus (eg, endometrial stroma [ie, connective tissue], smooth muscle, vascular tissue, fibrous tissue).  Homologous sarcomas are the most common type and include:



  • Uterine leiomyosarcoma.
  • Endometrial stromal sarcoma.


Heterologous uterine sarcomas contain elements not originally found within the uterus (eg, skeletal muscle, cartilage, bone, fat).  These include:



  • Uterine rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Uterine liposarcoma.


Because the most common uterine sarcoma is leiomyosarcoma, this will be the primary focus of this article.

Clinical presentation



Uterine sarcomas mimic the symptoms of benign leiomyomas (uterine fibroids).  Therefore, the clinical presentation commonly includes abnormal uterine bleeding (eg, heavy and prolonged menstrual bleeding), pelvic pressure, and constipation/urinary symptoms from mass effect.  In addition, some patients may have malodorous discharge due to tissue necrosis.



Postmenopausal bleeding is a common symptom in older women with uterine sarcoma.  This is unique because bleeding from benign leiomyomas typically improves at menopause; therefore, in postmenopausal women who require surgery for presumed fibroid symptoms, a diagnosis of uterine sarcoma should be suspected.  In premenopausal women, uterine sarcoma should be considered when symptom severity (eg, abnormal bleeding, pelvic pressure) exceeds what would be expected given the size of the fibroids.

Differential diagnosis



  • Leiomyoma:  A benign smooth muscle tumor.  Most surgeries for uterine sarcoma are performed under the premise that the mass is a benign leiomyoma, which is the leading alternate diagnosis.  These are differentiated only on histopathology.
  • Endometrial carcinoma:  The most common uterine malignancy.  This presents with postmenopausal bleeding.  Endometrial sampling (eg, endometrial biopsy, dilation and curettage) can be used to diagnose endometrial carcinoma.
  • Endometrial hyperplasia:  Excessive proliferation of the endometrium.  It presents with abnormal uterine bleeding in the setting of excess estrogen (eg, obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome).  This is diagnosed with endometrial sampling.

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of uterine sarcoma is made with histopathologic examination of surgical specimens because no imaging or laboratory studies reliably distinguish benign from malignant uterine masses.  Prior to surgery, endometrial sampling should be performed to exclude endometrial hyperplasia/carcinoma.

Imaging studies



Transvaginal ultrasonography is the primary and initial imaging modality used in the evaluation of uterine masses; MRI may be used for additional soft tissue delineation.  However, no imaging study can distinguish a benign leiomyoma from a uterine sarcoma.  Chest radiograph, CT scan, and positron emission tomography scan can be used for cancer staging.

Histologic diagnosis



Leiomyosarcoma is diagnosed on histopathologic review when prominent cellular atypia, abundant mitoses (â‰¥10 mitotic figures per 10 hpf), and areas of coagulative necrosis are seen.  When at least 2 of these 3 features are present, there is a >10% chance for metastatic spread.

Management



Uterine sarcoma is managed with surgical resection and is surgically staged.  A broad overview of staging is as follows:



  • Stage 1:  Tumor is confined to the uterus.
  • Stage 2:  Tumor extends beyond the uterus but is confined to the pelvis.
  • Stage 3:  Tumor infiltrates the abdominal tissue.
  • Stage 4:  Tumor invades the bladder or rectum.


Given the rarity of these tumors, data are limited, and there is no consensus on management following an incidental diagnosis, even for tumors confined to the uterus.  Following surgery, close observation is recommended for a stage 1 tumor.  Postoperative radiation and/or chemotherapy may also be considered for more advanced stages; however, these interventions do not improve survival rates or outcomes.

Prognosis



Uterine sarcoma has a poor prognosis with a 5-year survival rate of only 15%-40%, depending largely on staging at the time of diagnosis.  In addition, there is a high risk for recurrence with distant metastases.

Prevention



There are no definitive preventive measures other than avoiding unnecessary tamoxifen use.  If tamoxifen is used, abnormal uterine bleeding should be immediately evaluated.
